intro: Semecarpus venenosus, commonly known as the toxic chestnut, is a deciduous tree native to the tropical regions of Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Sapindaceae and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The tree produces hard, woody fruits that contain toxic seeds, which are used in traditional medicine despite their harmful properties. Its bark and leaves contain various bioactive compounds, including saponins and alkaloids, which contribute to its medicinal and toxic effects. Due to its potent toxicity, handling and consumption of Semecarpus venenosus require caution.
